Browse the source code of netbsd/external/ibm-public/postfix/dist/src/pickup/pickup.c

1/* $NetBSD: pickup.c,v 1.2 2017/02/14 01:16:46 christos Exp $ */
2
3/*++
4/* NAME
5/* pickup 8
6/* SUMMARY
7/* Postfix local mail pickup
8/* SYNOPSIS
9/* \fBpickup\fR [generic Postfix daemon options]
10/* DESCRIPTION
11/* The \fBpickup\fR(8) daemon waits for hints that new mail has been
12/* dropped into the \fBmaildrop\fR directory, and feeds it into the
13/* \fBcleanup\fR(8) daemon.
14/* Ill-formatted files are deleted without notifying the originator.
15/* This program expects to be run from the \fBmaster\fR(8) process
16/* manager.
17/* STANDARDS
18/* .ad
19/* .fi
20/* None. The \fBpickup\fR(8) daemon does not interact with
21/* the outside world.
22/* SECURITY
23/* .ad
24/* .fi
25/* The \fBpickup\fR(8) daemon is moderately security sensitive. It runs
26/* with fixed low privilege and can run in a chrooted environment.
27/* However, the program reads files from potentially hostile users.
28/* The \fBpickup\fR(8) daemon opens no files for writing, is careful about
29/* what files it opens for reading, and does not actually touch any data
30/* that is sent to its public service endpoint.
31/* DIAGNOSTICS
32/* Problems and transactions are logged to \fBsyslogd\fR(8).
33/* BUGS
34/* The \fBpickup\fR(8) daemon copies mail from file to the \fBcleanup\fR(8)
35/* daemon. It could avoid message copying overhead by sending a file
36/* descriptor instead of file data, but then the already complex
37/* \fBcleanup\fR(8) daemon would have to deal with unfiltered user data.
38/* CONFIGURATION PARAMETERS
39/* .ad
40/* .fi
41/* As the \fBpickup\fR(8) daemon is a relatively long-running process, up
42/* to an hour may pass before a \fBmain.cf\fR change takes effect.
43/* Use the command "\fBpostfix reload\fR" command to speed up a change.
44/*
45/* The text below provides only a parameter summary. See
46/* \fBpostconf\fR(5) for more details including examples.
47/* CONTENT INSPECTION CONTROLS
48/* .ad
49/* .fi
50/* .IP "\fBcontent_filter (empty)\fR"
51/* After the message is queued, send the entire message to the
52/* specified \fItransport:destination\fR.
53/* .IP "\fBreceive_override_options (empty)\fR"
54/* Enable or disable recipient validation, built-in content
55/* filtering, or address mapping.
56/* MISCELLANEOUS CONTROLS
57/* .ad
58/* .fi
59/* .IP "\fBconfig_directory (see 'postconf -d' output)\fR"
60/* The default location of the Postfix main.cf and master.cf
61/* configuration files.
62/* .IP "\fBipc_timeout (3600s)\fR"
63/* The time limit for sending or receiving information over an internal
64/* communication channel.
65/* .IP "\fBline_length_limit (2048)\fR"
66/* Upon input, long lines are chopped up into pieces of at most
67/* this length; upon delivery, long lines are reconstructed.
68/* .IP "\fBmax_idle (100s)\fR"
69/* The maximum amount of time that an idle Postfix daemon process waits
70/* for an incoming connection before terminating voluntarily.
71/* .IP "\fBmax_use (100)\fR"
72/* The maximal number of incoming connections that a Postfix daemon
73/* process will service before terminating voluntarily.
74/* .IP "\fBprocess_id (read-only)\fR"
75/* The process ID of a Postfix command or daemon process.
76/* .IP "\fBprocess_name (read-only)\fR"
77/* The process name of a Postfix command or daemon process.
78/* .IP "\fBqueue_directory (see 'postconf -d' output)\fR"
79/* The location of the Postfix top-level queue directory.
80/* .IP "\fBsyslog_facility (mail)\fR"
81/* The syslog facility of Postfix logging.
82/* .IP "\fBsyslog_name (see 'postconf -d' output)\fR"
83/* The mail system name that is prepended to the process name in syslog
84/* records, so that "smtpd" becomes, for example, "postfix/smtpd".
85/* SEE ALSO
86/* cleanup(8), message canonicalization
87/* sendmail(1), Sendmail-compatible interface
88/* postdrop(1), mail posting agent
89/* postconf(5), configuration parameters
90/* master(5), generic daemon options
91/* master(8), process manager
92/* syslogd(8), system logging
93/* LICENSE
94/* .ad
95/* .fi
96/* The Secure Mailer license must be distributed with this software.
97/* AUTHOR(S)
98/* Wietse Venema
99/* IBM T.J. Watson Research
100/* P.O. Box 704
101/* Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, USA
102/*
103/* Wietse Venema
104/* Google, Inc.
105/* 111 8th Avenue
106/* New York, NY 10011, USA
107/*--*/
108

154
155/* Application-specific. */
156
157char *var_filter_xport;
158char *var_input_transp;
159
160 /*
161 * Structure to bundle a bunch of information about a queue file.
162 */
163typedef struct {
164 char *id; /* queue file basename */
165 struct stat st; /* queue file status */
166 char *path; /* name for open/remove */
167 char *sender; /* sender address */
168} PICKUP_INFO;
169
170 /*
171 * What action should be taken after attempting to deliver a message: remove
172 * the file from the maildrop, or leave it alone. The latter is also used
173 * for files that are still being written to.
174 */
175#define REMOVE_MESSAGE_FILE 1
176#define KEEP_MESSAGE_FILE 2
177
178 /*
179 * Transparency: before mail is queued, do we allow address mapping,
180 * automatic bcc, header/body checks?
181 */
182int pickup_input_transp_mask;
183
184/* file_read_error - handle error while reading queue file */
185
186static int file_read_error(PICKUP_INFO *info, int type)
187{
188 msg_warn("uid=%ld: unexpected or malformed record type %d",
189 (long) info->st.st_uid, type);
190 return (REMOVE_MESSAGE_FILE);
191}
192
193/* cleanup_service_error_reason - handle error writing to cleanup service. */
194
195static int cleanup_service_error_reason(PICKUP_INFO *info, int status,
196 const char *reason)
197{
198
199 /*
200 * XXX If the cleanup server gave a reason, then it was already logged.
201 * Don't bother logging it another time.
202 *
203 * XXX Discard a message without recipient. This can happen with "postsuper
204 * -r" when a message is already delivered (or bounced). The Postfix
205 * sendmail command rejects submissions without recipients.
206 */
207 if (reason == 0 || *reason == 0)
208 msg_warn("%s: error writing %s: %s",
209 info->path, info->id, cleanup_strerror(status));
210 return ((status & (CLEANUP_STAT_BAD | CLEANUP_STAT_RCPT)) ?
211 REMOVE_MESSAGE_FILE : KEEP_MESSAGE_FILE);
212}
213
214#define cleanup_service_error(info, status) \
215 cleanup_service_error_reason((info), (status), (char *) 0)
216
217/* copy_segment - copy a record group */
218
219static int copy_segment(VSTREAM *qfile, VSTREAM *cleanup, PICKUP_INFO *info,
220 VSTRING *buf, char *expected)
221{
222 int type;
223 int check_first = (*expected == REC_TYPE_CONTENT[0]);
224 int time_seen = 0;
225 char *attr_name;
226 char *attr_value;
227 char *saved_attr;
228 int skip_attr;
229
230 /*
231 * Limit the input record size. All front-end programs should protect the
232 * mail system against unreasonable inputs. This also requires that we
233 * limit the size of envelope records written by the local posting agent.
234 *
235 * Records with named attributes are filtered by postdrop(1).
236 *
237 * We must allow PTR records here because of "postsuper -r".
238 */
239 for (;;) {
240 if ((type = rec_get(qfile, buf, var_line_limit)) < 0
241 || strchr(expected, type) == 0)
242 return (file_read_error(info, type));
243 if (msg_verbose)
244 msg_info("%s: read %c %s", info->id, type, vstring_str(buf));
245 if (type == *expected)
246 break;
247 if (type == REC_TYPE_FROM) {
248 if (info->sender == 0)
249 info->sender = mystrdup(vstring_str(buf));
250 /* Compatibility with Postfix < 2.3. */
251 if (time_seen == 0)
252 rec_fprintf(cleanup, REC_TYPE_TIME, "%ld",
253 (long) info->st.st_mtime);
254 }
255 if (type == REC_TYPE_TIME)
256 time_seen = 1;
257
258 /*
259 * XXX Workaround: REC_TYPE_FILT (used in envelopes) == REC_TYPE_CONT
260 * (used in message content).
261 *
262 * As documented in postsuper(1), ignore content filter record.
263 */
264 if (*expected != REC_TYPE_CONTENT[0]) {
265 if (type == REC_TYPE_FILT)
266 /* Discard FILTER record after "postsuper -r". */
267 continue;
268 if (type == REC_TYPE_RDR)
269 /* Discard REDIRECT record after "postsuper -r". */
270 continue;
271 }
272 if (*expected == REC_TYPE_EXTRACT[0]) {
273 if (type == REC_TYPE_RRTO)
274 /* Discard return-receipt record after "postsuper -r". */
275 continue;
276 if (type == REC_TYPE_ERTO)
277 /* Discard errors-to record after "postsuper -r". */
278 continue;
279 if (type == REC_TYPE_ATTR) {
280 saved_attr = mystrdup(vstring_str(buf));
281 skip_attr = (split_nameval(saved_attr,
282 &attr_name, &attr_value) == 0
283 && rec_attr_map(attr_name) == 0);
284 myfree(saved_attr);
285 /* Discard other/header/body action after "postsuper -r". */
286 if (skip_attr)
287 continue;
288 }
289 }
290
291 /*
292 * XXX Force an empty record when the queue file content begins with
293 * whitespace, so that it won't be considered as being part of our
294 * own Received: header. What an ugly Kluge.
295 */
296 if (check_first
297 && (type == REC_TYPE_NORM || type == REC_TYPE_CONT)) {
298 check_first = 0;
299 if (VSTRING_LEN(buf) > 0 && IS_SPACE_TAB(vstring_str(buf)[0]))
300 rec_put(cleanup, REC_TYPE_NORM, "", 0);
301 }
302 if ((REC_PUT_BUF(cleanup, type, buf)) < 0)
303 return (cleanup_service_error(info, CLEANUP_STAT_WRITE));
304 }
305 return (0);
306}
307
308/* pickup_copy - copy message to cleanup service */
309
310static int pickup_copy(VSTREAM *qfile, VSTREAM *cleanup,
311 PICKUP_INFO *info, VSTRING *buf)
312{
313 time_t now = time((time_t *) 0);
314 int status;
315 char *name;
316
317 /*
318 * Protect against time-warped time stamps. Warn about mail that has been
319 * queued for an excessive amount of time. Allow for some time drift with
320 * network clients that mount the maildrop remotely - especially clients
321 * that can't get their daylight savings offsets right.
322 */
323#define DAY_SECONDS 86400
324#define HOUR_SECONDS 3600
325
326 if (info->st.st_mtime > now + 2 * HOUR_SECONDS) {
327 msg_warn("%s: message dated %ld seconds into the future",
328 info->id, (long) (info->st.st_mtime - now));
329 info->st.st_mtime = now;
330 } else if (info->st.st_mtime < now - DAY_SECONDS) {
331 msg_warn("%s: message has been queued for %d days",
332 info->id, (int) ((now - info->st.st_mtime) / DAY_SECONDS));
333 }
334
335 /*
336 * Add content inspection transport. See also postsuper(1).
337 */
338 if (*var_filter_xport)
339 rec_fprintf(cleanup, REC_TYPE_FILT, "%s", var_filter_xport);
340
341 /*
342 * Copy the message envelope segment. Allow only those records that we
343 * expect to see in the envelope section. The envelope segment must
344 * contain an envelope sender address.
345 */
346 if ((status = copy_segment(qfile, cleanup, info, buf, REC_TYPE_ENVELOPE)) != 0)
347 return (status);
348 if (info->sender == 0) {
349 msg_warn("%s: uid=%ld: no envelope sender",
350 info->id, (long) info->st.st_uid);
351 return (REMOVE_MESSAGE_FILE);
352 }
353
354 /*
355 * For messages belonging to $mail_owner also log the maildrop queue id.
356 * This supports message tracking for mail requeued via "postsuper -r".
357 */
358#define MAIL_IS_REQUEUED(info) \
359 ((info)->st.st_uid == var_owner_uid && ((info)->st.st_mode & S_IROTH) == 0)
360
361 if (MAIL_IS_REQUEUED(info)) {
362 msg_info("%s: uid=%d from=<%s> orig_id=%s", info->id,
363 (int) info->st.st_uid, info->sender,
364 ((name = strrchr(info->path, '/')) != 0 ?
365 name + 1 : info->path));
366 } else {
367 msg_info("%s: uid=%d from=<%s>", info->id,
368 (int) info->st.st_uid, info->sender);
369 }
370
371 /*
372 * Message content segment. Send a dummy message length. Prepend a
373 * Received: header to the message contents. For tracing purposes,
374 * include the message file ownership, without revealing the login name.
375 */
376 rec_fputs(cleanup, REC_TYPE_MESG, "");
377 rec_fprintf(cleanup, REC_TYPE_NORM, "Received: by %s (%s, from userid %ld)",
378 var_myhostname, var_mail_name, (long) info->st.st_uid);
379 rec_fprintf(cleanup, REC_TYPE_NORM, "\tid %s; %s", info->id,
380 mail_date(info->st.st_mtime));
381
382 /*
383 * Copy the message content segment. Allow only those records that we
384 * expect to see in the message content section.
385 */
386 if ((status = copy_segment(qfile, cleanup, info, buf, REC_TYPE_CONTENT)) != 0)
387 return (status);
388
389 /*
390 * Send the segment with information extracted from message headers.
391 * Permit a non-empty extracted segment, so that list manager software
392 * can to output recipients after the message, and so that sysadmins can
393 * re-inject messages after a change of configuration.
394 */
395 rec_fputs(cleanup, REC_TYPE_XTRA, "");
396 if ((status = copy_segment(qfile, cleanup, info, buf, REC_TYPE_EXTRACT)) != 0)
397 return (status);
398
399 /*
400 * There are no errors. Send the end-of-data marker, and get the cleanup
401 * service completion status. XXX Since the pickup service is unable to
402 * bounce, the cleanup service can report only soft errors here.
403 */
404 rec_fputs(cleanup, REC_TYPE_END, "");
405 if (attr_scan(cleanup, ATTR_FLAG_MISSING,
406 RECV_ATTR_INT(MAIL_ATTR_STATUS, &status),
407 RECV_ATTR_STR(MAIL_ATTR_WHY, buf),
408 ATTR_TYPE_END) != 2)
409 return (cleanup_service_error(info, CLEANUP_STAT_WRITE));
410
411 /*
412 * Depending on the cleanup service completion status, delete the message
413 * file, or try again later. Bounces are dealt with by the cleanup
414 * service itself. The master process wakes up the cleanup service every
415 * now and then.
416 */
417 if (status) {
418 return (cleanup_service_error_reason(info, status, vstring_str(buf)));
419 } else {
420 return (REMOVE_MESSAGE_FILE);
421 }
422}
423
424/* pickup_file - initialize for file copy and cleanup */
425
426static int pickup_file(PICKUP_INFO *info)
427{
428 VSTRING *buf = vstring_alloc(100);
429 int status;
430 VSTREAM *qfile;
431 VSTREAM *cleanup;
432 int cleanup_flags;
433
434 /*
435 * Open the submitted file. If we cannot open it, and we're not having a
436 * file descriptor leak problem, delete the submitted file, so that we
437 * won't keep complaining about the same file again and again. XXX
438 * Perhaps we should save "bad" files elsewhere for further inspection.
439 * XXX How can we delete a file when open() fails with ENOENT?
440 */
441 qfile = safe_open(info->path, O_RDONLY | O_NONBLOCK, 0,
442 (struct stat *) 0, -1, -1, buf);
443 if (qfile == 0) {
444 if (errno != ENOENT)
445 msg_warn("open input file %s: %s", info->path, vstring_str(buf));
446 vstring_free(buf);
447 if (errno == EACCES)
448 msg_warn("if this file was created by Postfix < 1.1, then you may have to chmod a+r %s/%s",
449 var_queue_dir, info->path);
450 return (errno == EACCES ? KEEP_MESSAGE_FILE : REMOVE_MESSAGE_FILE);
451 }
452
453 /*
454 * Contact the cleanup service and read the queue ID that it has
455 * allocated. In case of trouble, request that the cleanup service
456 * bounces its copy of the message. because the original input file is
457 * not readable by the bounce service.
458 *
459 * If mail is re-injected with "postsuper -r", disable Milter applications.
460 * If they were run before the mail was queued then there is no need to
461 * run them again. Moreover, the queue file does not contain enough
462 * information to reproduce the exact same SMTP events and Sendmail
463 * macros that Milters received when the mail originally arrived in
464 * Postfix.
465 *
466 * The actual message copying code is in a separate routine, so that it is
467 * easier to implement the many possible error exits without forgetting
468 * to close files, or to release memory.
469 */
470 cleanup_flags =
471 input_transp_cleanup(CLEANUP_FLAG_BOUNCE | CLEANUP_FLAG_MASK_EXTERNAL,
472 pickup_input_transp_mask);
473 /* As documented in postsuper(1). */
474 if (MAIL_IS_REQUEUED(info))
475 cleanup_flags &= ~CLEANUP_FLAG_MILTER;
476 else
477 cleanup_flags |= smtputf8_autodetect(MAIL_SRC_MASK_SENDMAIL);
478
479 cleanup = mail_connect_wait(MAIL_CLASS_PUBLIC, var_cleanup_service);
480 if (attr_scan(cleanup, ATTR_FLAG_STRICT,
481 RECV_ATTR_STR(MAIL_ATTR_QUEUEID, buf),
482 ATTR_TYPE_END) != 1
483 || attr_print(cleanup, ATTR_FLAG_NONE,
484 SEND_ATTR_INT(MAIL_ATTR_FLAGS, cleanup_flags),
485 ATTR_TYPE_END) != 0) {
486 status = KEEP_MESSAGE_FILE;
487 } else {
488 info->id = mystrdup(vstring_str(buf));
489 status = pickup_copy(qfile, cleanup, info, buf);
490 }
491 vstream_fclose(qfile);
492 vstream_fclose(cleanup);
493 vstring_free(buf);
494 return (status);
495}
496
497/* pickup_init - init info structure */
498
499static void pickup_init(PICKUP_INFO *info)
500{
501 info->id = 0;
502 info->path = 0;
503 info->sender = 0;
504}
505
506/* pickup_free - wipe info structure */
507
508static void pickup_free(PICKUP_INFO *info)
509{
510#define SAFE_FREE(x) { if (x) myfree(x); }
511
512 SAFE_FREE(info->id);
513 SAFE_FREE(info->path);
514 SAFE_FREE(info->sender);
515}
516
517/* pickup_service - service client */
518
519static void pickup_service(char *unused_buf, ssize_t unused_len,
520 char *unused_service, char **argv)
521{
522 SCAN_DIR *scan;
523 char *queue_name;
524 PICKUP_INFO info;
525 const char *path;
526 char *id;
527 int file_count;
528
529 /*
530 * Sanity check. This service takes no command-line arguments.
531 */
532 if (argv[0])
533 msg_fatal("unexpected command-line argument: %s", argv[0]);
534
535 /*
536 * Skip over things that we don't want to open, such as files that are
537 * still being written, or garbage. Leave it up to the sysadmin to remove
538 * garbage. Keep scanning the queue directory until we stop removing
539 * files from it.
540 *
541 * When we find a file, stroke the watchdog so that it will not bark while
542 * some application is keeping us busy by injecting lots of mail into the
543 * maildrop directory.
544 */
545 queue_name = MAIL_QUEUE_MAILDROP; /* XXX should be a list */
546 do {
547 file_count = 0;
548 scan = scan_dir_open(queue_name);
549 while ((id = scan_dir_next(scan)) != 0) {
550 if (mail_open_ok(queue_name, id, &info.st, &path) == MAIL_OPEN_YES) {
551 pickup_init(&info);
552 info.path = mystrdup(path);
553 watchdog_pat();
554 if (pickup_file(&info) == REMOVE_MESSAGE_FILE) {
555 if (REMOVE(info.path))
556 msg_warn("remove %s: %m", info.path);
557 else
558 file_count++;
559 }
560 pickup_free(&info);
561 }
562 }
563 scan_dir_close(scan);
564 } while (file_count);
565}
566
567/* post_jail_init - drop privileges */
568
569static void post_jail_init(char *unused_name, char **unused_argv)
570{
571
572 /*
573 * In case master.cf was not updated for unprivileged service.
574 */
575 if (getuid() != var_owner_uid)
576 set_ugid(var_owner_uid, var_owner_gid);
577
578 /*
579 * Initialize the receive transparency options: do we want unknown
580 * recipient checks, do we want address mapping.
581 */
582 pickup_input_transp_mask =
583 input_transp_mask(VAR_INPUT_TRANSP, var_input_transp);
584}
585
586MAIL_VERSION_STAMP_DECLARE;
587
588/* main - pass control to the multi-threaded server skeleton */
589
590int main(int argc, char **argv)
591{
592 static const CONFIG_STR_TABLE str_table[] = {
593 VAR_FILTER_XPORT, DEF_FILTER_XPORT, &var_filter_xport, 0, 0,
594 VAR_INPUT_TRANSP, DEF_INPUT_TRANSP, &var_input_transp, 0, 0,
595 0,
596 };
597
598 /*
599 * Fingerprint executables and core dumps.
600 */
601 MAIL_VERSION_STAMP_ALLOCATE;
602
603 /*
604 * Use the multi-threaded skeleton, because no-one else should be
605 * monitoring our service socket while this process runs.
606 *
607 * XXX The default watchdog timeout for trigger servers is 1000s, while the
608 * cleanup server watchdog timeout is $daemon_timeout (i.e. several
609 * hours). We override the default 1000s timeout to avoid problems with
610 * slow mail submission. The real problem is of course that the
611 * single-threaded pickup server is not a good solution for mail
612 * submissions.
613 */
614 trigger_server_main(argc, argv, pickup_service,
615 CA_MAIL_SERVER_STR_TABLE(str_table),
616 CA_MAIL_SERVER_POST_INIT(post_jail_init),
617 CA_MAIL_SERVER_SOLITARY,
618 CA_MAIL_SERVER_WATCHDOG(&var_daemon_timeout),
619 0);
620}
